Xinyu Zhou School of Computer Science & Engineering and ERI@N, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore Jun Zhao School of Computer Science & Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore Huimei Han School of Computer Science & Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore Claude Guet School of Physical & Mathematical Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore
(December 2020)
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) is an intriguing distributed machine learning approach due to its privacy-preserving characteristics. To balance the trade-off between energy and execution latency, and thus accommodate different demands and application scenarios, we formulate an optimization problem to minimize a weighted sum of total energy consumption and completion time through two weight parameters. The optimization variables include bandwidth, transmission power and CPU frequency of each device in the FL system, where all devices are linked to a base station and train a global model collaboratively. Through decomposing the non-convex optimization problem into two subproblems, we devise a resource allocation algorithm to determine the bandwidth allocation, transmission power, and CPU frequency for each participating device. We further present the convergence analysis and computational complexity of the proposed algorithm. Numerical results show that our proposed algorithm not only has better performance at different weight parameters (i.e., different demands) but also outperforms the state of the art.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, FDMA, resource allocation.

I Introduction

To create a model with high accuracy, machine learning (ML) needs a large size of high-quality training data. Due to limitations of user privacy, data security and competition among industries, usually the data is limited. Besides, the concern around data privacy is rising. Related laws and regulations are appearing, such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) of the European Union (EU), so it becomes more challenging to collect sensitive data together for learning a model. Therefore, federated learning (FL) could be a solution to collaboratively train an ML model while preserving data on its local device distributedlyÂ [1]. FL is a special distributed learning framework, which was proposed by Google in [2]. The algorithm in [2] was called FedAvg. In FedAvg, each device trains a model locally for a certain number of local iterations and uploads their parameters to a base station periodically to build a shared global model.

Challenges and motivation. On account of the huge number of parameters in prevalent ML models, FL has high requirements of device memory, computational capability and communication bandwidth. The limited communication and computation resources in the real world bring several challenges to the deployment of FL: (1) Limited bandwidth results in long latency between clients and the server and consequently affects the convergence time of the global model. (2) A large amount of energy is needed because a satisfactory model requires plenty of local computation and communication rounds. (3) Due to the large size of current ML models, low-battery devices with limited computation resources have difficulties in joining an FL framework [3]. To improve the efficiency of FL, it is crucial to save both communication and computation resources, which can be achieved by reducing communication overheadÂ [4, 5, 6] or finding optimal resource (e.g., transmission power, bandwidth, CPU frequency, etc.) allocation strategiesÂ [7, 3, 8]. This paper focuses on the latter solution. An optimal resource allocation strategy will allow us to reduce the execution latency and energy consumption, and accelerate the convergence of the global model. Therefore, it is essential to consider how to adjust bandwidth, transmission power and CPU clock frequency for each participating device to jointly optimize energy consumption and completion time (i.e., delay). Moreover, different scenarios have different energy and latency demands. For example, connected autonomous vehicles in a smart transportation system require low-latency control decisions, while personal computers may tolerate higher latency to utilize the idle time to train their model. Thus, it raises the following question: how to allocate the transmit power, bandwidth and CPU frequency to each user device to find the optimal trade-off between energy consumption and the total completion time of the FL system while accommodating to different scenarios?

Motivated by the above question, we consider a basic FL system via frequency-division multiple access (FDMA) and formulate a joint optimization of energy and delay problem over a wireless network. The objective function includes a weighted sum of the total energy consumption and the total completion time. Given a certain weight for a specific application scenario, we can find a trade-off between energy and execution latency. The participating devices in FL are under power and bandwidth constraints while pursuing as little energy and time consumption as possible.

Contributions. In summary, the main contributions of this paper are listed as follows:

  • â€¢

    We introduce the joint optimization of energy and delay framework into the design of a federated learning system via FDMA. The objective is to optimize a weighted sum of energy consumption and total completion time so that it can satisfy diverse requirements.

  • â€¢

    The optimization problem includes a sum-of-ratio form of communication energy consumption, which is non-convex and cannot be solved through traditional optimization techniques. To tackle this problem, we first propose to decompose the original problem into two subproblems: the first subproblem is to minimize computation energy and completion time, and the second is to minimize the communication energy. The first one can be solved through its Lagrangian dual problem. The second subproblem is a sum-of-ratio minimization problem, and we transform it into a convex subtractive-form problem through a Newton-like method similar to [9] used for solving a general fractional programming problem. Convergence analysis and time complexity are provided.

  • â€¢

    Numerical results show: 1) at different weight parameters (i.e., different requirements), our resource allocation algorithm is able to find a corresponding solution to jointly minimize energy consumption and completion time. 2) Our joint optimization frameworkâ€™s performance is better than the communication-only optimization and computation-only optimization framework. 3) Our resource allocation scheme outperforms the state of the art, especially when there is a tight delay constraint.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II presents related works. In Section III, we introduce the FL model and the necessary notations. Problem formulation is provided in Section IV. We detail the proposed algorithm in Section V. Then SectionÂ VI provides the convergence and the computational complexity of the algorithm. Numerical results are shown in Section VII. Finally, Section VIII concludes the paper.

II Related Work

In this section, we survey related research. SectionÂ II-A as the first subsection is devoted to federated learning (FL) over wireless networks which our paper is also about. Then in SectionÂ II-B, we elaborate on other FL studies. Finally, since our paper tackles resource allocation and appears in ICDCS, SectionÂ II-C presents related works on resource allocation in other distributed systems.

II-A Federated Learning over Wireless Networks

For simplicity, below we use WFL, short for wireless federated learning, to describe FL over wireless networks. In many papersÂ [10, 8, 11, 12, 3], the base station (i.e., the aggregator) is also seen as an edge server, so the literature may also use the term federated edge learning (FEEL). Since our paper minimizes the weighted sum of two metrics: energy consumption and delay, our coverage about WFL next is categorized into energy minimization, delay minimization, optimization of other metrics, weighted optimization, and non-optimization studies, respectively. Note that papersÂ [8, 13, 3] minimizing the weighted sum of energy and delay are elaborated in the part about weighted optimization. During the discussion, we also compare our work with many studies including [7, 14, 10, 12, 15, 8, 13, 3].

Minimizing the energy consumption in WFL. Three representative papersÂ [7, 12, 10] minimize the energy consumption only in WFL are explained as follows.

YangÂ etÂ al.Â [7] minimize the sum of all devicesâ€™ energy consumption, which includes the local computation energy and the wireless transmission energy. In [7], devices access the wireless transmission media via FDMA, as in our paper. The optimization variables in [7] include the local training accuracy and each deviceâ€™s transmission time per global round, bandwidth allocation, CPU frequency and transmit power. The constraints cover an upper bound on the total delay and a lower bound on each deviceâ€™s transmission time per global round such that the local model can be uploaded.

The major difference between [7] and our work is that the optimization objective is just the energy consumption inÂ [7], but is the weighted sum of the energy and delay in our paper. The consideration of both energy and delay in the objective function makes our optimization much more difficult to solve thanÂ [7], as explained below. Since we put the total completion time into the objective function, a part of our optimization problem (i.e., Subproblem 2 in (11) later) becomes an NP-complete problemâ€”the sum-of-ratios problem [9]. While addressing a weaker optimization objective than our work,Â [7] has two more optimization variables than ours: the local training accuracy and each deviceâ€™s transmission time per global round. Yet, since both two variables can be decoupled from others, their optimal values can be easily obtained as in Theorem 2 ofÂ [7]. The rest variables of [7] are the same as ours. However, if just minimizing the total energy consumption, it will be easy to decouple the optimization problem into two subproblems as [7] does. Since all subproblems in [7] are convex, [7] can easily obtain the optimal solution.

Different fromÂ [7] and our paper which both consider only CPU computing resources at devices, LiÂ etÂ al.Â [10] and ZengÂ etÂ al.Â [12] incorporate devicesâ€™ GPU computation for WFL. In particular,Â [10] studies GPU only, whileÂ [12] uses CPU and GPU simultaneously. The energy consumption model for GPU is different from that of CPU used in our paper, so we omit the detailed discussions ofÂ [10, 12].

Minimizing the delay in WFL. Below we discuss three workÂ [14, 15, 3] on delay minimization only in WFL.

Minimizing the delay by YangÂ etÂ al.Â [14] is actually used to provide an initial feasible solution for the problem of minimizing the energy consumption subject to the delay constraint inÂ [7]. In other words, the work done inÂ [14] is a subroutine of that inÂ [7]. We have discussed above how our optimization is more challenging to solve than that ofÂ [7], so our work is further more difficult thanÂ [14]. InÂ [14], the FDMA bandwidth allocation is not analyzed directly, but a bisection method is used to sandwich the minimum delay.

Distinct fromÂ [14] considering FDMA just like its extended versionÂ [7], the researchÂ [15] by ChenÂ etÂ al. employs orthogonal frequency-division multiple access (OFDMA) for delay minimization in WFL. In OFDMA, the radio is divided into 2-dimensional resource blocks (RBs) over time and frequency. The optimization variables inÂ [15] include device selection matrices and RB allocation matrices, which all have binary elements. Hence,Â [15] handles binary integer programming, while the variables inÂ [14] and our paper are all continuous.

Optimizing other metrics in WFL. Other metrics in WFL have also been optimized, such as the number of global aggregation roundsÂ [16], the total number of bits sent from the devices to the aggregatorÂ [17], the admission data rates of all devicesÂ [18], the communication errorÂ [19], the total communication costÂ [20] with each communication link being assigned a cost number, the training lossÂ [11, 21, 22], the learning efficiencyÂ [23, 24], and a metric capturing the long-term performance of WFLÂ [25].

Weighted optimization in WFL. Below we review three workÂ [8, 13, 3] on the weighted minimization of energy consumption and delay in WFL.

The major difference between [8] and our paper is that the channel access method in [8] for devices is time-division multiple access (TDMA), while our paper adopts FDMA. In addition, although the optimization variables in [8] also include parameters capturing local training and global training progresses respectively, the two parameters are optimized just by a numerical method: an exhaustive grid search. Other optimization variables in [8] include each deviceâ€™s CPU frequency and transmission time per global round (we do not discuss additional variables listed in [8] since they can be decided from variables already explained).

InÂ [13], the optimization variables include the number of local iterations per global round, the number of global rounds, and the number of devices selected (via uniform samling) per global round. Hence,Â [13] tackles integer programming, while the variables inÂ [8] and our paper are all continuous.

In contrast toÂ [8, 13] which have only a two-level hierarchy: the base station (often also an edge server) and the devices,Â [3] adopts a three-level hierarchy (introduced also byÂ [26]): an cloud server, multiple edge servers, and the devices. A detailed comparison betweenÂ [3] and our paper is as follows. Firstly, the optimization variables in both work include each deviceâ€™s bandwidth allocation via FDMA and CPU frequency, whileÂ [3] also considers edge association of devices, and our paper also optimizes each deviceâ€™s transmission power. Secondly, in our work, a challenge in solving the optimization arises from the coupling between the FDMA bandwidth allocation and the weighted minimization of energy and delay. Yet,Â [3] avoids such challenge by simplifying the Shannon formula for devicesâ€™ data rates. In particular, in Equation (5) ofÂ [3], the noise power as the denominator inside the logarithm of the Shannon formula is forcefully assumed as a constant that does not scale with the allocated bandwidth, while it should the noise power spectral density times the bandwidth. Such extreme simplification inÂ [3] makes the bandwidth allocation easy to solve. In this paper, we use the exact expression of the Shannon formula and hence run into a much more challenging optimization.

The workÂ [27] also considers weighted optimization in WFL, but is not about energy consumption or delay.

Studies other than optimizing metrics in WFL. Beyond optimization studies, WFL has also been investigated in terms of scheduling policiesÂ [28, 29, 30], and mobility-based orchestrationÂ [31].

II-B Other Federated Learning Studies

In addition to federated learning over wireless networks elucidated in the previous subsection, we present other federated learning work in this subsection.

Communication-efficient FL. Researchers have enabled FL to be more communication-efficient, by transmitting clustered model updatesÂ [32], avoiding irrelevant updatesÂ [4], adaptive parameter freezingÂ [6], and sketchingÂ [33].

Security/privacy of FL. Security of FL has been addressed by defending against Byzantine attacksÂ [34], and enforcing device liabilityÂ [35]. Privacy of FL is examined inÂ [36, 37].

Incentives in FL. Designing incentive mechanisms for FL has been tackled inÂ [38, 39].

Machine learning approaches to improve FL. FL systems have also benefited from other machine learning techniques including reinforcement learningÂ [40], meta learningÂ [41, 42], one-shot learningÂ [43], and online learningÂ [5].

Applications of FL. FL has been applied to various tasks including crowdsensingÂ [44, 45, 46], RFID clone detectionÂ [47], and the classification of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs)Â [48].

II-C Resource Allocation in Other Distributed Systems

Resource allocation has also been studied in other distributed systems, such as blockchainÂ [49, 50], cloud computingÂ [51, 52], edge computingÂ [53], distributed learningÂ [54, 55], and wireless networksÂ [56].

The system model is FL over wireless communications. We consider a star network with a base station, as shown in Fig. 1. We suppose that the base station serves Nğ‘N devices. The set of Nğ‘N devices is denoted by ğ’©ğ’©\mathcal{N}.

The base station uses all the uploaded parameters to calculate the weighted average model parameter and broadcasts it to each device, where the weight for each device nğ‘›nâ€™s parameter is DnDsubscriptğ·ğ‘›ğ·\frac{D_{n}}{D}; i.e., the fraction of device nğ‘›nâ€™s number of data points over the total number of data points. The above uploading and broadcasting process is called global communication.

FDMA. In this paper, different devices communicate with the base station via FDMA. FL over FDMA has also been studied inÂ [14, 10, 7, 3] (see Section II for detailed comparisons between these work and ours). FDMA is simple to implement even for mobile devices with limited computation capabilityÂ [10]. We do not consider OFDMA since our optimization problem with FDMA is already difficult to tackle. AlthoughÂ [15] adopts OFDMA for FL, but it addresses delay minimization only and handles binary integer programming, while the variables in our paper are all continuous. In addition, TDMA over FL is investigated inÂ [8, 23].

We will formulate a joint optimization of energy and completion time problem in FL via FDMA. The objective function is a weighted sum of total energy and time. Total energy consumption and total completion time are discussed in SectionsÂ III-A andÂ III-B, respectively.

III-A Total Energy Consumption

The total energy consumption, Eğ¸E, comprises wireless network transmission energy consumption and local computation energy consumption. Following works [8, 3, 7], we do not consider the energy consumption of the base station (or the central server), either.

III-A1 Transmission energy consumption

Generally, transmission time refers to the uplink time and the downlink time. However, since the output power of the base station is significantly larger than the maximum uplink transmission power of a user device, the downlink time is much smaller than the uplink time. Thus, we neglect the downlink time.

From the Shannon formula, we express the data transmission rate, rnsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘›r_{n}, as

rn=Bnâ€‹log2â¡(1+gnâ€‹pnN0â€‹Bn),subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘›subscriptğµğ‘›subscript21subscriptğ‘”ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0subscriptğµğ‘›\displaystyle r_{n}=B_{n}\log_{2}(1+\frac{g_{n}p_{n}}{N_{0}B_{n}}), (1)

where Bnsubscriptğµğ‘›B_{n} is the bandwidth allocated to user nğ‘›n, N0subscriptğ‘0N_{0} is the power spectral density of Gaussian noise, gnsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘›g_{n} is the channel gain between user device nğ‘›n and the base station and pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n} is the transmission power. Note that there is no interference in FDMA since the channels assigned to users are separated by different frequencies.

Strictly speaking, the expression (1) describes just the maximum theoretical bit rate achievable in a wireless channel. The actual data rate depends on the spectral efficiency of the communication technology. Yet, we use (1) as the data rate for simplicity as in much prior workÂ [14, 10, 7, 8, 23] on FL. Also, if â€œ==â€ in (1) is replaced by â€œâ‰¤\leqâ€, â€œ==â€ will still be taken in our optimization problem to save the transmission time and hence the transmission energy.

IV Optimization Problem Formulation

To minimize the total energy consumption as well as the total completion time of the whole FL training process, we use a weighted sum method to formulate the optimization problem. As Encâ€‹mâ€‹psuperscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘šğ‘E_{n}^{cmp} in (5), Entâ€‹râ€‹aâ€‹nâ€‹ssuperscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘›ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘ E_{n}^{trans} in (3), Tnuâ€‹psuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘T_{n}^{up} in (2) and Tncâ€‹mâ€‹psuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘šğ‘T_{n}^{cmp} in (7) are highly related to pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n}, Bnsubscriptğµğ‘›B_{n} and fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n}, we choose pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n}, Bnsubscriptğµğ‘›B_{n} and fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} as three optimization variables. Some works may consider more optimization variables such as the global communication rounds Rgsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘”R_{g}, the local computations rounds Rlsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘™R_{l} or the model accuracy. However, Rgsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘”R_{g}, Rlsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘™R_{l} and the model accuracy are determined by the exact ML model run on each device. To make our optimization problem apply to flexible scenarios and broad use cases, we do not consider more optimization variables.

with w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1}, w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2} âˆˆ[0,1]absent01\in[0,1] denoting two weight parameters of total energy consumption and completion time and w1+w2=1subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤21w_{1}+w_{2}=1. Constraint (8a) and constraint (8b) set the ranges of the transmission power and computation frequency of each device. Constraint (8c) refers to the uplink bandwidth constraint.

Note that the max function in (8) makes the optimization hard to solve. To circumvent this difficulty, we replace the max function by an auxiliary variable ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} with an additional constraint; then, the problem writes as:

Constraint (9a) is the total time constraint.

Difficulty of solving problem (9). Since the formulation of Tnuâ€‹psuperscriptsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›ğ‘¢ğ‘T_{n}^{up} and constraint (9a) are not convex, problem (9) is non-convex and thus can be difficult to solve. Consequently, we must explore other ways to transform this problem to make it solvable. Additionally, the complex problem formulation increases the difficulty of transforming this problem.

IV-A Problem Decomposition

To continuously transform problem (9) into a more simple form, we must decompose the problem. Because pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n} and Bnsubscriptğµğ‘›B_{n} are in the same term, we thereby separate problem (9) into two subproblems. One has pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n} and Bnsubscriptğµğ‘›B_{n} as optimization variables and the other has fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} and ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} as optimization variables.

Two minimization problems are as follows:

Subproblem 1
minfn,ğ’¯subscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ’¯\displaystyle\min_{f_{n},\mathcal{T}} w1â€‹Rgâ€‹âˆ‘n=1NÎºâ€‹Rlâ€‹cnâ€‹Dnâ€‹fn2+w2â€‹Rgâ€‹ğ’¯subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘…ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘ğœ…subscriptğ‘…ğ‘™subscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›2subscriptğ‘¤2subscriptğ‘…ğ‘”ğ’¯\displaystyle~{}w_{1}R_{g}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\kappa R_{l}c_{n}D_{n}f_{n}^{2}+w_{2}R_{g}\mathcal{T} (10)
subject to: (8b),(9a).
Subproblem 2
minpn,Bnsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğµğ‘›\displaystyle\min_{p_{n},B_{n}} w1â€‹Rgâ€‹âˆ‘n=1Npnâ€‹dnBnâ€‹log2â¡(1+pnâ€‹gnN0â€‹Bn)subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘…ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğµğ‘›subscript21subscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘”ğ‘›subscriptğ‘0subscriptğµğ‘›\displaystyle~{}w_{1}R_{g}\sum_{n=1}^{N}p_{n}\frac{d_{n}}{B_{n}\log_{2}(1+\frac{p_{n}g_{n}}{N_{0}B_{n}})} (11)
subject to: (8a),Â (8c),(9a).

Our strategy is to randomly choose feasible (ğ’‘,ğ‘©)ğ’‘ğ‘©(\bm{p},\bm{B}) at first, and solve Subproblem 1 to get the optimal ğ’‡ğ’‡\bm{f}. Then, we solve Subproblem 2 to get the optimal (ğ’‘,ğ‘©)ğ’‘ğ‘©(\bm{p},\bm{B}). The whole process consists of iteratively solving Subproblems 1 and 2 until convergence.

V Solution of The joint optimization problem

In this section, we will explain how to solve Subproblems 1 and 2.

To solve a convex optimization problem, a typical approach is to use the Karushâ€“Kuhnâ€“Tucker (KKT) conditions. For readerâ€™s convenience, we briefly describe KKT below while more details can be found in Section 5.5.3 of a book by BoydÂ etÂ al.Â [57]. V-D Resource Allocation Algorithm

Until now, we have already solved Subproblem 1 and Subproblem 2. Here we give the complete resource allocation algorithm in Algorithm 2.

Algorithm 2 first initializes a feasible solution according to the range of power ğ’‘ğ’‘\bm{p} and bandwidth ğ‘©ğ‘©\bm{B} and the sum of the bandwidth of each device cannot exceed BğµB. Then, solving problem (17) with given (ğ’‘,ğ‘©)ğ’‘ğ‘©(\bm{p},\bm{B}) can make sure we get an optimal ğ’‡ğ’‡\bm{f} at this step. Subproblem 2 does not include ğ’‡ğ’‡\bm{f} and it is an optimization problem which focuses on ğ’‘ğ’‘\bm{p} and ğ‘©ğ‘©\bm{B}.

VI Convergence and Time Complexity

In this section, we analyze the convergence of our resource allocation algorithm (Algorithm 2) and present the time complexity of Algorithm 2.

VI-A Convergence Analysis

In Algorithm 2, given (ğ’‘(kâˆ’1),ğ‘©(kâˆ’1))superscriptğ’‘ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘©ğ‘˜1(\bm{p}^{(k-1)},\bm{B}^{(k-1)}) at iteration kğ‘˜k, we can obtain an optimal solution ğ’‡(k)superscriptğ’‡ğ‘˜\bm{f}^{(k)} of problem (17).

Then, Algorithm 1 is called in Algorithm 2, so next we discuss the convergence of Algorithm 1. To simplify the notation, we define ğœ¶:=(ğœ·,ğ‚)assignğœ¶ğœ·ğ‚\bm{\alpha}:=(\bm{\beta},\bm{\nu}).

According to Theorem 3.2 in [9], if the following three conditions hold: (i) Ï•â€‹(ğœ¶)italic-Ï•ğœ¶\phi(\bm{\alpha}) is differentiable and satisfies the Lipschitz condition in a solution set Î©Î©\Omega, (ii) assume a number L>0ğ¿0L>0 such that for ğœ¶ğŸ,ğœ¶ğŸsubscriptğœ¶1subscriptğœ¶2\bm{\alpha_{1}},\bm{\alpha_{2}} âˆˆÎ©absentÎ©\in\Omega,

â€–Ï•â€²â€‹(ğœ¶ğŸ)âˆ’Ï•â€²â€‹(ğœ¶ğŸ)â€–â‰¤Lâ€‹â€–ğœ¶ğŸâˆ’ğœ¶ğŸâ€–,normsuperscriptitalic-Ï•â€²subscriptğœ¶1superscriptitalic-Ï•â€²subscriptğœ¶2ğ¿normsubscriptğœ¶1subscriptğœ¶2\displaystyle||\phi^{\prime}(\bm{\alpha_{1}})-\phi^{\prime}(\bm{\alpha_{2}})||\leq L||\bm{\alpha_{1}}-\bm{\alpha_{2}}||, (41)

and (iii) there exits a number M>0ğ‘€0M>0 so that for each ğœ¶âˆˆÎ©ğœ¶Î©\bm{\alpha}\in\Omega,

â€–[Ï•â€²â€‹(ğœ¶)]âˆ’1â€–â‰¤M,normsuperscriptdelimited-[]superscriptitalic-Ï•â€²ğœ¶1ğ‘€\displaystyle||[\phi^{\prime}(\bm{\alpha})]^{-1}||\leq M, (42)

then no matter at which starting point ğœ¶0âˆˆÎ©superscriptğœ¶0Î©\bm{\alpha}^{0}\in\Omega, (5) and (31) in Algorithm 1 will converge to a unique solution of Ï•â€‹(ğœ¶)=0italic-Ï•ğœ¶0\phi(\bm{\alpha})=0 in a linear rate. In addition, the convergence rate in the solutionâ€™s neighborhood is quadratic.

Ï•â€‹(ğœ¶)italic-Ï•ğœ¶\phi(\bm{\alpha}) in Algorithm 1 is actually linear and it is easy to prove it satisfies the Lipshitz condition and the conditions (41) (42). Therefore, Algorithm 1 converges with a linear rate at any starting point ğœ¶0âˆˆÎ©superscriptğœ¶0Î©\bm{\alpha}^{0}\in\Omega and a quadratic convergence rate of the solutionâ€™s neighborhood.

Therefore, iteratively solving Subproblem 1 to get ğ’‡ğ’‡\bm{f} and Subproblem 2 to get (ğ’‘,ğ‘©ğ’‘ğ‘©\bm{p},\bm{B}) will converge eventually.

VI-B Time Complexity

For Algorithm 1, we can use floating point operations (flops) to count the time complexity. One real addition/multiplication/division is counted as one flop. We mainly focus on analyzing Steps 3â€“6 because they take a major part of computational complexity. Step 3 needs 2â€‹N2ğ‘2N flops. Step 4 utilizes CVX to solve problem SP2_v2. Besides, CVX invokes an interior-point algorithm to solve Semidefinite Programming (SDP) problems. Thus, given the solution accuracy Ïµ1>0subscriptitalic-Ïµ10\epsilon_{1}>0, the worst time complexity is ğ’ªâ€‹(N4.5â€‹logâ¡1Ïµ1)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘4.51subscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}(N^{4.5}\log\frac{1}{\epsilon_{1}}) [59]. Additionally, Step 5 will take ğ’ªâ€‹((j+1)â€‹N)ğ’ªğ‘—1ğ‘\mathcal{O}((j+1)N) flops. In fact, jğ‘—j is a small number usually. If j=0ğ‘—0j=0 (i.e., Î¾j=1superscriptğœ‰ğ‘—1\xi^{j}=1), Step 6 is just the Newton method. Otherwise, it is a Newton-like method. Therefore, the convergence rate is superlinear or quadratic [9]. Obviously, Step 6 takes 4â€‹N4ğ‘4N flops. Since the number of iterations is not larger than i0subscriptğ‘–0i_{0}, the time complexity of Algorithm 1 will not exceed ğ’ªâ€‹(i0â€‹(N4.5â€‹logâ¡1Ïµ1+(j+1)â€‹N))ğ’ªsubscriptğ‘–0superscriptğ‘4.51subscriptitalic-Ïµ1ğ‘—1ğ‘\mathcal{O}(i_{0}(N^{4.5}\log\frac{1}{\epsilon_{1}}+(j+1)N)).

As for Algorithm 2, it solves two subproblems successively through using the convex package CVX in each iteration. Steps 3 and 4 both use CVX to solve two subproblems. As we have mentioned above, the time complexity caused by CVX is ğ’ªâ€‹(N4.5â€‹logâ¡1Ïµ1)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘4.51subscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}(N^{4.5}\log\frac{1}{\epsilon_{1}}) given a solution accuracy Ïµ1>0subscriptitalic-Ïµ10\epsilon_{1}>0. Step 4 invokes Algorithm 1, and we have already analyzed the time complexity of Algorithm 1. With the aforementioned time complexity of Algorithm 1, the overall complexity is ğ’ªâ€‹(Kâ€‹(i0+1)â€‹N4.5â€‹logâ¡1Ïµ1+Kâ€‹i0â€‹(j+1)â€‹N)ğ’ªğ¾subscriptğ‘–01superscriptğ‘4.51subscriptitalic-Ïµ1ğ¾subscriptğ‘–0ğ‘—1ğ‘\mathcal{O}(K(i_{0}+1)N^{4.5}\log\frac{1}{\epsilon_{1}}+Ki_{0}(j+1)N).

VII Experiments

We will conduct extensive experiments to illustrate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm. We first present the parameter setting of our experiments in SectionÂ VII-A, and then report various experimental results in other subsections.

VII-A Parameter Setting

For most experimental settings, we use the settings used in [7]. In the experiments, Nğ‘N denoting the number of devices is 50. The devices are uniformly located in a circular area of size 500500500 m Ã—\times 500500500 m and the center is a base station. The channelâ€™s pass loss is modeled as 128.1+37.6â€‹logâ¡(distance)128.137.6distance128.1+37.6\log(\texttt{distance}) along with the standard deviation of shadow fading, which is 888 dB, and the unit of distance is kilometer. The power spectral density of Gaussian noise N0subscriptğ‘0N_{0} is âˆ’174174-174 dBm/Hz.

Additionally, the default number of local iterations Rlsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘™R_{l} is set as 10 and the number of global aggregations Rgsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘”R_{g} is 400. The data size for each device to upload is set as 28.128.128.1 kbits. Besides, each device has 500500500 samples. The number of CPU cycles per sample, cnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›c_{n}, is chosen randomly from [1,3]Ã—10413superscript104[1,3]\times 10^{4}. The effective switched capacitance Îºğœ…\kappa is 10âˆ’28superscript102810^{-28}. The maximum frequency fnmâ€‹aâ€‹xsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥f_{n}^{max} and the maximum transmission power pnmâ€‹aâ€‹xsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥p_{n}^{max} for all devices are 222 GHz and 121212 dBm, respectively. The minimum transmission power pnmâ€‹iâ€‹nsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›p_{n}^{min} is set as 00 dBm. The total bandwidth BğµB is 202020 MHz.

VII-B How does Our Optimization Algorithm Perform with respect to System Parameters?

In this section, we study the effect of system parameters on our optimization problem. The system parameters include: weight parameters, the number of devices, global rounds & local iterations, and the radius of the circular area for generating different devices.

Weight parameters. In our optimization problem, we have two weight parameters w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1} and w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2}. The sum of them always equals to 111. If w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1} is greater than w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2}, energy consumption will take a more dominant position in our optimization problem. Analogously, if w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2} is larger than w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1}, it is more important to optimize time instead of energy.

In Fig. 2(a), Fig. 2(b), Fig. 3(a) and Fig. 3(b), we compare five pairs of (w1,w2)=(0.9,0.1),(0.7,0.3),(0.5,0.5),(0.3,0.7),(0.1,0.9)subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤20.90.10.70.30.50.50.30.70.10.9(w_{1},w_{2})=(0.9,0.1),(0.7,0.3),(0.5,0.5),(0.3,0.7),(0.1,0.9) with a benchmark algorithm. There are six lines in those figures. (w1,w2)=(0.9,0.1)subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤20.90.1(w_{1},w_{2})=(0.9,0.1) and (0.7,0.3)0.70.3(0.7,0.3) are to simulate devices under a low-battery condition, so the weight parameter w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1} of the energy consumption is larger than the weight parameter w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2} of the time consumption. (w1,w2)=(0.5,0.5)subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤20.50.5(w_{1},w_{2})=(0.5,0.5) represents the normal scenario, which means no preference for the time or energy. Besides, (w1,w2)=(0.1,0.9)subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤20.10.9(w_{1},w_{2})=(0.1,0.9) and (0.3,0.7)0.30.7(0.3,0.7) stand for the time-sensitive scenario, so w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2} is larger than w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1}. In brief, the algorithms in our comparison include:

  • â€¢

    Our proposed algorithm with weight parameters (w1=0.9,w2=0.1)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¤10.9subscriptğ‘¤20.1(w_{1}=0.9,w_{2}=0.1), (w1=0.7,w2=0.3)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¤10.7subscriptğ‘¤20.3(w_{1}=0.7,w_{2}=0.3), (w1=0.5,w2=0.5)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¤10.5subscriptğ‘¤20.5(w_{1}=0.5,w_{2}=0.5), (w1=0.3,w2=0.7)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¤10.3subscriptğ‘¤20.7(w_{1}=0.3,w_{2}=0.7) and (w1=0.1,w2=0.9)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¤10.1subscriptğ‘¤20.9(w_{1}=0.1,w_{2}=0.9).

  • â€¢

    The benchmark algorithm: 1) When comparing energy consumption and completion time at different maximum transmission power limits, for the nğ‘›n-th device, randomly select the CPU frequency fnsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›f_{n} from 0.1 to 2 GHz and set pn=pmâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›superscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥p_{n}=p^{max}, Bn=BNsubscriptğµğ‘›ğµğ‘B_{n}=\frac{B}{N}. 2) When comparing at different maximum CPU frequencies, randomly select the transmission power pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n} between 0 and 12 dBm and set fn=fmâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›superscriptğ‘“ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥f_{n}=f^{max}, Bn=BNsubscriptğµğ‘›ğµğ‘B_{n}=\frac{B}{N}.

To be more general, we run our algorithm at each pair of weight parameters 100 times and take the average value of energy and time consumption. At each time, we will generate 50 users randomly. Readers may wonder why the simulation plots do not show confidence intervals. This is because at each time, we only generate users randomly. For the same group of users, our algorithm will produce the same result for each operation if we do not change any system parameter. We only want to observe the overall performance of our optimization algorithm at different pairs of weight parameters (w1,w2)subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤2(w_{1},w_{2}).

Fig. 2(a) and Fig. 2(b) show the results of total energy consumption and total time consumption with five pairs of (w1,w2)subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤2(w_{1},w_{2}) at different maximum transmit power limits, respectively. It can be observed clearly that when w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1} becomes larger and w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2} decreases, the total energy consumption becomes smaller and the total time becomes larger. The reason is that if w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1} (resp., w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2}) increases, our optimization algorithm will pay more attention to minimizing the energy cost (resp., time consumption).

Additionally, in Fig. 2(a), the green, dark blue, light blue, yellow and red lines are all below the benchmark line with a wide gap, which means our algorithm obtains better total energy consumption even at w1=0.1subscriptğ‘¤10.1w_{1}=0.1 (this means the algorithm mainly focuses on minimizing the total time consumption instead of energy).

Correspondingly, Fig. 2(b) reveals that our time optimization is still better than the benchmark except for w1=0.9subscriptğ‘¤10.9w_{1}=0.9 and w2=0.1subscriptğ‘¤20.1w_{2}=0.1 after pmâ€‹aâ€‹x=7superscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥7p^{max}=7 dBm. We analyze that it is caused by finding a better solution to minimize the total energy consumption through sacrificing the total time cost.

Fig. 3(a) and Fig. 3(b) compare the total energy consumption and delay at different maximum CPU frequencies. Obviously, with the increase of the maximum CPU frequency, energy consumption of the benchmark algorithm is rising, which can be seen in Fig. 3(a). Intuitively, if the CPU frequency is set at the maximum, the time consumption will be reduced. Therefore, in Fig. 3(b), the total time consumption of the benchmark algorithm is decreasing as CPU frequency increases. However, it only performs better than our algorithm when w1=0.9subscriptğ‘¤10.9w_{1}=0.9 and w2=0.1subscriptğ‘¤20.1w_{2}=0.1 after the maximum CPU frequency =0.6absent0.6=0.6 GHz. The reason is our algorithm mainly focuses on optimizing the energy when w1=0.9subscriptğ‘¤10.9w_{1}=0.9 and w2=0.1subscriptğ‘¤20.1w_{2}=0.1, so our algorithmâ€™s energy consumption is the smallest in Fig. 3(a).

Besides, five lines related to our algorithm in Fig. 3(a) and Fig. 3(b) all enter a stationary phase after a certain maximum CPU frequency. This is because we have already found the optimal frequency for each device at that weight parameters. Thus, there will not be any change with the increasing fmâ€‹aâ€‹xsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥f^{max}.

The number of devices. We also explore the effect of the number of devices on the total energy consumption and the time consumption. We assume the total number of samples is 25000 and distribute all the data equally to each device.

It can be observed in Fig.Â 4(a) that with the increase of the number of devices, the total energy consumption decreases. This is caused by the decreasing number of samples allocated to each device as the number of devices increases, which saves the computation energy. In Fig.Â 4(b), the overall trend is decreasing. As we have mentioned, because we increase the number of devices, the number of samples assigned to each device decreases, and the computation time cost decreases. While, for the green line at the bottom in Fig.Â 4(b), the total delay increases slightly as the number of devices increases. Since our algorithm optimizes a weighted sum of the energy and delay, sometimes the increase in the delay is to achieve lower energy consumption.

The radius of the circular area. Fig.Â 5(a) and Fig.Â 5(b) show the change in energy and time consumption as the area used for generating users randomly increases. There are three lines in each figure representing 20, 50, 80 devices, respectively. Fig.Â 5(a) does not reveal a clear correlation between energy consumption and the radius. Since the number of samples of each device is always 500 in this setting, as the number of devices increases, the overall computation energy consumption must increase unless the CPU frequency is set lower. Whereas, if the CPU frequency/transmission power is set lower, the computation time/transmission time cost becomes larger. This explains why the total energy consumption of these three lines suddenly drops at 0.90.90.9 km. Since the CPU frequency/transmission power is set lower, the total energy consumption decreases at 0.90.90.9 km. Fig.Â 5(b) clearly shows the time consumption and the radius are positively correlated. Intuitively, the transmission time will increase as the radius increases if the transmission power is kept constant. To save the time consumption, our optimization algorithm cannot always put the energy consumption first. Therefore, at 1.31.31.3 km, the CPU frequency and transmission power much be set larger than the previous settings so that the time consumption will not rise much higher.

The communication/computation rounds. We choose five kinds of global communication rounds Rgsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘”R_{g}: 50, 100, 200, 300, 400. Fig.Â 6(a) and Fig.Â 6(b) show how the energy consumption and time cost change with the increase in the number of local iterations Rlsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘™R_{l} per global round. It can be seen that as Rlsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘™R_{l} and Rgsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘”R_{g} become larger, the total energy and time consumption both increase. They are positively correlated.

The number of samples on each device. If we keep all the system parameters consistent and just vary the number of samples on each device, we find that Dnsubscriptğ·ğ‘›D_{n} is positively correlated with time and energy. This result is consistent with the analytical expression of the optimization objective. Due to the space limitation, we do not provide experiments where different devices have various numbers of samples.

VII-C Joint Communication & Computation Optimization vs. Communication/Computation Optimization Only

To study the domination relationship between the transmission energy and computation energy, we compare our algorithm with the following schemes at the aspect of total energy consumption at different maximum completion time limits. The maximum transmission power is pmâ€‹aâ€‹x=10superscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥10p^{max}=10 dBm. We denote the maximum delay of the whole training process as Tğ‘‡T. Tğ‘‡T is fixed to compare these three schemes, and we set w1=1subscriptğ‘¤11w_{1}=1 and w2=0subscriptğ‘¤20w_{2}=0 in our algorithm.

  • â€¢

    Communication optimization only: Each deviceâ€™s computation frequency is set as a fixed value. We optimize only the transmission power and bandwidth allocated to each device. To guarantee there is a feasible solution, we set the fixed frequency value for each device as Rgâ€‹Rlâ€‹cnâ€‹Dnğ’¯âˆ’Rgâ€‹maxâ¡(dn/rn)subscriptğ‘…ğ‘”subscriptğ‘…ğ‘™subscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›ğ’¯subscriptğ‘…ğ‘”subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘›\frac{R_{g}R_{l}c_{n}D_{n}}{\mathcal{T}-R_{g}\max(d_{n}/r_{n})}, which is derived from constraint (9a), and rnsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘›r_{n} is calculated from the initial bandwidth and transmission power.

  • â€¢

    Computation optimization only: Each deviceâ€™s transmission power and bandwidth are fixed and we optimize only the CPU frequency. The transmission power and bandwidth of device nğ‘›n are set as pn=pmâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›superscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥p_{n}=p^{max} and Bn=B2â€‹Nsubscriptğµğ‘›ğµ2ğ‘B_{n}=\frac{B}{2N}. Such setting gives better simulation results than letting pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n} be pmâ€‹aâ€‹x2superscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥2\frac{p^{max}}{2} and/or Bnsubscriptğµğ‘›B_{n} be BNğµğ‘\frac{B}{N}, and is also used in the source code of [7].

Apparently, it can be observed from Fig. 8 that our proposed algorithm performs better than the other two schemes. In addition, transmission energy takes the lead of the total energy consumption. Only optimizing the computation energy cannot exceed the performance of only optimizing the transmission energy. Furthermore, we are able to discover the conflicting relationship between maximum completion time and total energy consumption. As maximum completion time increases, there will be better solutions to reduce total energy consumption. However, if we relax the constraint of the maximum completion time Tğ‘‡T too much, the optimal solution will reach the minimum limit of transmission power and CPU frequency. That is the reason why the gap of these three lines becomes small when Tğ‘‡T is large.

VII-D Superiority of Our Algorithm over Existing Work

Prior to our study, the state of the art for FL with FDMA is [7] by Yang etÂ al. on energy optimization subject to the delay constraint. In the comparison below, we refer to their method as Scheme 1. Scheme 1 has two more optimization variables, which are local accuracy and the delay. To be fair, we only use the method (Algorithm 3 in [7]) that they use to optimize the transmission power, the bandwidth and the CPU frequency of each user. Since the optimization of the local accuracy and delay is a separate section in Scheme 1, it will not affect the comparison between our method and Scheme 1.

The maximum completion time is not included in the objective function of the optimization problem in SchemeÂ 1. Instead, it appears as a constraint. Therefore, to be fair, we set a fixed maximum completion time Tğ‘‡T to compare our optimization algorithm with Scheme 1. With a fixed maximum completion time Tğ‘‡T, our minimization problem (9) is under the condition that w1=1subscriptğ‘¤11w_{1}=1 and w2=0subscriptğ‘¤20w_{2}=0. Besides, the initial transmission power and bandwidth of device nğ‘›n are set as pn=pmâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›superscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥p_{n}=p^{max}, Bn=B2â€‹Nsubscriptğµğ‘›ğµ2ğ‘B_{n}=\frac{B}{2N}. The comparison result is shown in Fig. 8. From Fig. 8, we can find that each line of our proposed algorithm is below the corresponding line of Scheme 1, which reveals that our algorithmâ€™s performance is better. Additionally, as the maximum completion time Tğ‘‡T decreases, the total energy consumption gap between our algorithm and Scheme 1 gets larger, thereby indicating that our proposed algorithm leads to a better solution when the maximum completion time Tğ‘‡T is small. Therefore, our proposed algorithm will show more superiority for the training scenario with a restricted delay.

At T3=150subscriptğ‘‡3150T_{3}=150 s, the line of our algorithm first decreases and then slightly increases. This is because our initial transmission power is initialized as pn=pmâ€‹aâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›superscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥p_{n}=p^{max} at the start of our optimization algorithm. After finding the optimal solution at a specific pmâ€‹aâ€‹xsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥p^{max}, the subsequent total energy consumption will slightly increase due to the different starting point from the previous step as pmâ€‹aâ€‹xsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥p^{max} continues increasing.

VIII Conclusion

In our paper, we have investigated the bandwidth allocation, transmission power control and CPU frequency of each participating device in federated learning. Through introducing two weight parameters w1subscriptğ‘¤1w_{1} and w2subscriptğ‘¤2w_{2}, we optimized a weighted sum of energy consumption and total completion time. By adjusting two weight parameters, the corresponding resource allocation strategy can be found. Additionally, this makes our resource allocation scheme more flexible and amenable to different requirements of the FL system. In the experiments, we can observe that our resource allocation algorithm improves the state of the art especially when there is a tight constraint in terms of the total completion time.
